results.title: Tom Rockmore, Brandom, Hegel and inferentialism
results.snippet: In the course of developing a semantics with epistemological intent, Brandom claims that his inferentialism is Hegelian. This paper argues that, even on a charitable reading, Brandom is an anti-Hegelian.

results.title: David L. Marshall, The implications of Robert Brandom's inferentialism for intellectual history
results.snippet: It shows how Brandom’s work emerged out of the broad shift in the philosophy of language from semantics to pragmatics that also informed speech act theory. The article then goes on to unpack the rich implications of Brandom’s inferentialism for the theory and practice of intellectual history.

results.title: Jaroslav Peregrin, What is inferentialism?
results.snippet: Inferentialism is the conviction that to be meaningful in the distinctively human way, or to have a 'conceptual content', is to be governed by a certain kind of inferential rules.

results.snippet: We investigate the relations among Brandom’s three dimensions of semantic inferential articulation, namely, incompatibility entailments, committive consequences, and permissive consequences. results.title: Daniel Laurier, Making "Reasons" Explicit: How Normative is Brandom's Inferentialism
results.snippet: I show that Brandom's claim that these concepts are analogous to the concepts of obligation and permission cannot be right, and argue that the normative character of the concept of commitment is dubious. This leads me to replace Brandom's conception of inferential relations as relations between deontic statuses with one according to which they are to be seen as relations between entitlements and acknowledgements of commitments

results.title: John MacFarlane, Pragmatism and inferentialism
results.snippet: I’ll argue that pragmatism, as Brandom initially describes it—the view that “semantics must answer to pragmatics”—does not favor an inferentialist approach to semantics over a truth-conditional one.

results.title: Robert B. Brandom & Ivan Ivashchenko, The Commitment to Inference
results.snippet: In this conversation, American philosopher Robert Brandom talks about the historical background of his inferentialism, reconstructing the influence of his teachers Wilfrid Sellars and Richard Rorty.

results.title: Julien Murzi & Florian Steinberger, Inferentialism
results.snippet: It discusses some of the benefits of logical inferentialism, chiefly with regard to the epistemology of logic, and considers a number of objections. The chapter critically examines Robert Brandom's inferentialism about linguistic and conceptual content in general.
